--- title: "Day 3A" format: html: css: ../styles.css highlight-style: github --- ![](../img/memory_2780E3.svg){.hero} We finish up our final section on data wrangling by discussing the reshaping of columns and entire tibbles with the separate, unite, and pivot functions. We then discuss how to combine data from multiple tibbles or data files with the same/similar formats (e.g., separate files per participant) and how to join related/linked data that is spread across multiple tibbles or data files (e.g., separate files for different variables of the same participants). ## Slides [Click here to view the slides in their own window.](./Slides/3A_Slides.html) ## Data Files If you want to follow along with the part where we read in data from multiple files, run this code to generate some example files: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) # Create three tibbles with simulated daily diary data df1 <- tibble(day = 1:30, mood = round(rnorm(30, 5, 1))) df2 <- tibble(day = 1:30, mood = round(rnorm(30, 4, 1))) df3 <- tibble(day = 1:30, mood = round(rnorm(30, 4, 2))) # Create a subfolder in your project folder called data dir.create("data") # Write each tibble to a CSV file in the data folder write_csv(df1, file = "data/pid_001.csv") write_csv(df2, file = "data/pid_002.csv") write_csv(df3, file = "data/pid_003.csv") ``` ::: ## Practice 1 Examine the `table5` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) and tidy it up using `separate()` and `unite()`. End with variables for country, four-digit year (YYYY), number of tuberculosis cases, and population.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) table5 |> unite( col = "year", century, year, sep = "" ) |> separate_wider_delim( col = rate, delim = "/", names = c("cases", "population") ) ## # A tibble: 6 Ã— 4 ## country year cases population ## ## 1 Afghanistan 1999 745 19987071 ## 2 Afghanistan 2000 2666 20595360 ## 3 Brazil 1999 37737 172006362 ## 4 Brazil 2000 80488 174504898 ## 5 China 1999 212258 1272915272 ## 6 China 2000 213766 1280428583 ``` :::

## Practice 2 Reshape the `billboard` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) to a long format such that each row represents a single trackâ€™s ranking for a single week (variables: `artist`, `track`, `date.entered`, `week`, `rank`). For a challenge, remove the prefix from your final week variable and convert it into a numeric variable.

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} billboard |> pivot_longer( cols = starts_with("wk"), names_to = "week", values_to = "rank", names_prefix = "wk", # Challenge names_transform = parse_number # Challenge ) ## # A tibble: 24,092 Ã— 5 ## artist track date.entered week rank ## ## 1 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 1 87 ## 2 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 2 82 ## 3 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 3 72 ## 4 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 4 77 ## 5 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 5 87 ## 6 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 6 94 ## 7 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 7 99 ## 8 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 8 NA ## 9 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 9 NA ## 10 2 Pac Baby Don't Cry (Keep... 2000-02-26 10 NA ## # â„¹ 24,082 more rows ``` :::

## Practice 3 Reshape the `table2` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) so that each row represents a single country in a single year (Hint: variables should be `country`, `year`, `cases`, and `population`).

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} table2 |> pivot_wider(names_from = type, values_from = count) ## # A tibble: 6 Ã— 4 ## country year cases population ## ## 1 Afghanistan 1999 745 19987071 ## 2 Afghanistan 2000 2666 20595360 ## 3 Brazil 1999 37737 172006362 ## 4 Brazil 2000 80488 174504898 ## 5 China 1999 212258 1272915272 ## 6 China 2000 213766 1280428583 ``` :::

## Practice 4 Install and load the \{Lahman\} package, which contains data about baseball teams and players. a. Explore how the `People`, `Batting`, and `Salaries` tables are connected. b. How would you join this data to compare the salaries of right-handed and left-handed batters? Do so using a \{tidyverse\} function and select only the relevant variables. *Note: These tables are data frames not tibbles (so they will print a **lot** of rows). To fix this, you can use `x <- as_tibble(x)` to convert them to tibbles.*

Click here for the answer key
**Answer (a)** All three tables are connected via the `playerID` variable. **Answer (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(Lahman) # must be installed first joined_data <- inner_join(People, Salaries, by = "playerID") |> select(playerID, nameFirst, nameLast, bats, yearID, teamID, salary) |> as_tibble() |> print() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 26,428 Ã— 7 playerID nameFirst nameLast bats yearID teamID salary 1 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2004 SFN 300000 2 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2007 CHA 387500 3 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2008 BOS 403250 4 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2009 SEA 419000 5 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2010 SEA 2750000 6 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2011 SEA 4500000 7 aardsda01 David Aardsma R 2012 NYA 500000 8 aasedo01 Don Aase R 1986 BAL 600000 9 aasedo01 Don Aase R 1987 BAL 625000 10 aasedo01 Don Aase R 1988 BAL 675000 # â„¹ 26,418 more rows ``` ::: :::

## Practice 5 a. Join the `band_members` and `band_instruments` tibbles (included in \{tidyverse\}) using all four basic types of joins. Compare the results. b. Now join the `band_members` and `band_instruments2` tibbles in a way that adds the instrument played by each name in `band_members.`

Click here for the answer key
**Answer (a)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} left_join(band_members, band_instruments, by = "name") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} right_join(band_members, band_instruments, by = "name") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass 3 Keith guitar ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} inner_join(band_members, band_instruments, by = "name") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 Ã— 3 name band plays 1 John Beatles guitar 2 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} full_join(band_members, band_instruments, by = "name") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 4 Ã— 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass 4 Keith guitar ``` ::: ::: **Answer (b)** ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} left_join(band_members, band_instruments2, by = c("name" = "artist")) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 3 Ã— 3 name band plays 1 Mick Stones 2 John Beatles guitar 3 Paul Beatles bass ``` ::: :::

## Practice 6 Explore what happens when you join two tables with duplicated/repeated keys. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} x <- tibble( key = c(1, 2, 2, 3), val_x = c("x1", "x2", "x3", "x4") ) y <- tibble( key = c(1, 2, 2, 3), val_y = c("y1", "y2", "y3", "y4") ) ``` :::

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} left_join(x, y, by = "key") ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning in left_join(x, y, by = "key"): Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`. â„¹ Row 2 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`. â„¹ Row 2 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`. â„¹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship = "many-to-many"` to silence this warning. ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 Ã— 3 key val_x val_y 1 1 x1 y1 2 2 x2 y2 3 2 x2 y3 4 2 x3 y2 5 2 x3 y3 6 3 x4 y4 ``` ::: ::: The key gets duplicated for each pairwise combination.

## Challenge 1 Reshape the `us_rent_income` tibble (included in \{tidyverse\}) so that each row represents a single US state (Hint: Variables should be something like: `GEOID`, `NAME`, `estimate_income`, `estimate_rent`, `moe_income`, and `moe_rent`)

Click here for the answer key
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} us_rent_income |> pivot_wider( names_from = variable, values_from = c(estimate, moe) ) ## # A tibble: 52 Ã— 6 ## GEOID NAME estimate_income estimate_rent moe_income moe_rent ## ## 1 01 Alabama 24476 747 136 3 ## 2 02 Alaska 32940 1200 508 13 ## 3 04 Arizona 27517 972 148 4 ## 4 05 Arkansas 23789 709 165 5 ## 5 06 California 29454 1358 109 3 ## 6 08 Colorado 32401 1125 109 5 ## 7 09 Connecticut 35326 1123 195 5 ## 8 10 Delaware 31560 1076 247 10 ## 9 11 District of Columbia 43198 1424 681 17 ## 10 12 Florida 25952 1077 70 3 ## # â„¹ 42 more rows ``` :::

## Readings - [Pivoting](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/articles/pivot.html) from *tidy* package website - [Two-table verbs](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/two-table.html) from *dplyr* package website - [Chapter 6: Data tidying](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-tidy.html) from *R4DS* (2E) - [Section 8.4: Reading data from multiple files](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/data-import.html#sec-readr-directory) from *R4DS* (2E) - [Chapter 20: Joins](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/joins.html) from *R4DS* (2E) ## Fun Stuff ### Pivot! If only Chandler had studied data reshaping, he would know what pivot means... {{< video https://youtu.be/8w3wmQAMoxQ >}} ### Merge! At least he wasn't asking to hang an "inner join" sign... ðŸ¤£ {{< video https://youtu.be/lP2pz7E7hm4 >}} ::: {.text-center} Continue to Day 3B Materials  » :::
